description: From Middle English relik et al., from Old French relique, from Latin reliquiae (“remains, relics”), from relinquō (“I leave behind, abandon, relinquish”), from re- + linquō (“I leave, quit, forsake, depart from”).

entries.meaning: That which remains; that which is left after loss or decay; a remaining portion.
examples: Synonyms: remnant, remainder, residue; see also Thesaurus:remainder

entries.meaning: Something old and outdated, possibly kept for sentimental reasons.
examples: Published in 1982, the now out-of-print computer guide is a real relic, full of dozens of black-and-white pictures of large, bulky computers that you would sooner find in the Smithsonian than on anybody's desk today.

entries.meaning: (religion) A part of the body of a saint, or an ancient religious object, kept for veneration.

verbs.description: relic (third-person singular simple present relics, present participle relicing or relicking, simple past and past participle reliced or relicked)

entries.meaning: (transitive, uncommon, often of guitars) To cause (an object) to appear old or worn, to distress.
